importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the fraudulent call involving a fake voice of Defence Minister Guido Crosetto was reported, marking the beginning of a significant AI voice scam targeting Italian businessmen.
The date when Defence Minister Guido Crosetto publicly revealed he had received a call from a purported 'friend' asking about his mobile number, exposing the scam and prompting public awareness.
The date when Resemble AI reported that global losses from deepfake scams had risen to $347 million between January and June 2025, indicating a growing trend of AI-powered fraud.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which AI-generated voice scams, including those targeting Italian businessmen and US citizens, have surged in frequency and sophistication, highlighting an urgent rise in AI misuse.

keyTakeAways: AI voice technology has advanced to the point where generated voices are indistinguishable from real human voices, especially when trained on real voice data.
A recent scam targeted Italian businessmen with deepfake calls from Defence Minister Guido Crosetto, who was not involved, asking for money to free kidnapped journalists.
The scam included fake calls from a 'General' and targeted prominent figures such as Giorgio Armani and Patrizio Bertelli, with only Massimo Moratti sending money.
AI-generated voice clones are now rated as more trustworthy than real voices by participants in research, indicating a dangerous level of realism and deception.
Between January and June 2025, over $547 million has been lost globally to deepfake scams, with the figure rising from $200 million to $347 million.
AI-generated deepfakes are being used to create fake news, manipulate public perception, and produce illegal sexual content, including child sexual abuse material.

In response, US President Donald Trump signed a federal law criminalizing the publication of AI-generated intimate images without consent, and Australia banned a deepfake app used to generate nude images.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A surge in AI-powered deepfake voice scams has emerged, with a notable case targeting Italian businessmen who received calls from a fake Defence Minister Guido Crosetto, asking for over 1 million euros to free kidnapped journalists. The scam, which occurred in February 2025, exploited AI voice cloning technology that can mimic real human speech with high realism, making it indistinguishable from actual voices. Research by Queen Mary University of London found that AI voice clones are rated as equally trustworthy as real voices, and participants were more likely to believe AI voices than real ones. Global losses from such scams have increased dramatically, with over $547 million lost between January and June 2025. The technology also enables the creation of fake news, illicit sexual content, and deepfakes of real people. In response, the US and Australia have introduced legal measures to criminalize the publication of AI-generated intimate images, highlighting growing global concern over AI’s misuse in fraud and abuse.
title: AI now sounds more like us – should we be concerned?
